head.title: 45 Bowls Of Risotto On the Wall . . .

hedline.hl1: 45 Bowls Of Risotto On the Wall . . .

abstract.p: Risottos are special dish at new Risoterria at 270 Bleecker Street; photo (S)

block.p: So many risottos, so little time. The new Risotteria at 270 Bleecker Street (Morton Street) has 45 combinations ($6.50 to $10.50), in flavors like salami and parsley, asparagus and saffron, calamari with olives and peppers, roasted Italian sausage and spinach, and pesto and mozzarella. And of course, the classic, with Parmesan.

The choices multiply to 135 if you consider there are three kinds of Italian rice to choose from: arborio, carnaroli and vialone nano. Arborio is the type usually used. Carnaroli is a short-grained rice preferred by connoisseurs. Vialone nano, especially popular in Venice, results in a moister risotto.

Joseph Pace, right, an owner of this innovative venture, formerly worked at Bouley and Petrossian. He parcooks the rice so that he needs only another three minutes to finish the cooking. The risottos are also sold for takeout: heating takes 30 seconds in a microwave oven. Panini and salads round out the menu.
